awd_titl_txt: CNH2-S: Measuring adaptive responses that strengthen governance of marine resources in small coastal fishing communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine social-ecological systems (SES) are shaped by many related social and environmental processes, such as ocean warming and acidification, human migration, and seafood trade. Together, these environmental and social processes have major influences on coastal marine ecosystems and the human communities that depend on them. They affect abundance and diversity of marine species, shape social and economic life within a community, and influence systems of governance. Understanding these effects is particularly relevant for small-scale fisheries as they employ over 90% of fishers globally and provide food and labor opportunities for hundreds of millions of people. This study will identify and evaluate responses to social and environmental change that shape the governance and sustainability of natural resource systems. The focal SES of this study encompasses small-scale fisheries. After 25 collaborative projects conducted over the last 20 years, the research team is well-positioned to create a model for SES synthesis and analysis that is grounded in knowledge from diverse disciplines and perspectives and is relevant to small-scale fisheries in coastal marine systems and communities around the globe. The project will build capacity in integrated SES science by supporting an early career investigator and education and training activities for graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral scholars. In addition, it will develop interdisciplinary collaboration in marine conservation and management, lead to information-sharing through further development of an open source digital platform, and engage decision makers, fishers, and other community members through workshop activities.

This project will produce novel and generalizable insights concerning the operation and transformation of integrated socio-environmental systems (SES) and improve scientific understanding of adaptive responses to environmental and social change in a culturally and economically important transboundary marine ecosystem. The focus is on the SESs associated with small-scale fisheries and the work is guided by the overall research question: What are the observed responses, either adaptive or maladaptive, to social and environmental drivers of change that shape the governance and sustainability of natural resources and the human communities that depend on them? The investigators will synthesize diverse datasets covering oceanographic, ecological, fishery, socioeconomic, and governance system components that the team has assembled through previous research projects and sustained engagement with regional stakeholders and ecosystems. They will use a series of spatially explicit and hierarchically structured models, informed by expert knowledge of individuals with diverse disciplinary and institutional perspectives, to test hypotheses related to 1) the frequency and spatial extent of environmental and social drivers of change; 2) influences of these drivers on governance arrangements; and 3) the ability of cooperative governance arrangements to withstand shocks and exhibit adaptive strategies in the face of change. The goal is to understand causal pathways and processes leading to divergent socio-environmental outcomes and contribute to the theory of adaptation in practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed the following research question: What are the observed responses, either adaptive or maladaptive, to social and environmental drivers of change that shape the governance and sustainability of natural resources and the human communities that depend on them? We examined this question in the context of the social-ecological systems (SES) associated with small-scale fisheries (SSF) in the Mexican state of Baja California Sur (BCS). Our principal goal was to determine the causal pathways and processes leading to divergent socio-ecological outcomes and to contribute to the theory and understanding of adaptation in practice. We achieved this goal through the following activities: (1) Synthesis of environmental and social drivers of change in the literature in general and in the social-ecological context of Baja California, Mexico in particular, (2) Integrated socio-environmental system analyses, (3) Transdisciplinary knowledge production and dissemination, and (4) Capacity-building aimed at conducting and applying integrated SES science among various local actors.

 

Activity one focused on assessing the spatial and temporal distribution of key environmental and social drivers of change. For it, we compiled and analyzed data from 23 social, ecological, oceanographic, and governance indicators relevant to small-scale fisheries. We also used this information to select five communities for in-depth analysis.

 

For activity two we conducted integrated analyses using the datasets obtained from the first activity. This resulted in the preparation of three manuscripts out of which one was already published. In addition, through the opportunities generated by this and earlier NSF projects, team members contributed insights and expertise to a total of 12 manuscripts and 1 book chapter.

 

In relation to activity three, we developed and implemented strategies to disseminate the findings to a diverse group of actors, including fishers and their representatives, local, state and federal government decision-makers, researchers from local universities and research centers, and practitioners from local and national civil society organizations. Despite the constraints and delays imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic, we successfully organized a series of meetings and workshops at the early, mid, and final stages of the project. During these workshops we solicited and received input on all the major aspects of our project, including the discussion and interpretation of the results from our analyses. This strategy allowed us to keep our research contextually and empirically relevant while testing the fundamental theory related to environmental governance, cooperation, and adaptive capacity. Furthermore, we presented findings from this work at 14 international conferences and symposia.

 

Finally, for activity four, we organized and convened two rounds of a virtual seminar series (fall 2021 and fall 2022) to showcase applications of integrated social-environmental system analyses. The seminar series was promoted throughout the Americas and featured eight case studies from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, and Peru and emphasized theoretical, methodological, and empirical aspects that need to be taken into consideration when developing an integrated social-environmental system scientific approach. The target audience for the seminars included U.S. and Latin American graduate students, scholars, and practitioners. Overall, the seminar series was attended by 179 participants from 23 countries and 87 institutions. For the lineup of speakers and topics please see https://dmc.umaine.edu/fall2021_ses_seminars/ and https://sites.nicholas.duke.edu/xavierbasurto/upcoming-seminars-fall-2022/
